NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (infml)  a taxi driver
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Cabbie, how far is it to Johnson Street?

NewWords.WordPhrase: be absorbed in, be fully occupied with 专心致志于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was lost in thought, staring at the book in front of him.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (AmE) the glass window in the front of a car, truck, etc. (汽车的)挡风玻璃
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Since I couldn't find my friend, I wrote him a note and stuck it on the windshield of his car.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a taxi 出租车
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The cabs were lined up outside the station.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. able to be used, had or reached 可用的;可得到的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Details of the competition are available from our head office.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. showing or saying that one is sorry for some fault or wrong 道歉地,带着歉意地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Finally the boy's parents appeared and gave him a hug apologetically.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) (used when you are not very sure about what you have just said) 诸如此类的事
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Here's some money. Get yourself a sandwich or something.

NewWords.WordPhrase: continue; begin
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. "Could I ask you a rather personal question?" "Of course, go ahead."

NewWords.WordPhrase: memorize, remember exactly 记住，能背出
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The pupils were required to learn the poems by heart.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. form a judgement about 估计
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We haven't estimated the proper price for the contract yet.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 不妨,(也)无妨
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The weather was so bad we might (just) as well have stayed at home.

NewWords.WordPhrase: not a good 不太好的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is not much of a father, but he is an outstanding professor.

NewWords.WordPhrase: continue without stopping 保持
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They risk losing their homes because they can no longer keep up the repayments.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  the act of writing, receiving or sending letters; letters 通信(联系);信件
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His interest in writing came from a long correspondence with a close friend.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. almost
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The holidays are practically over; there's only one day left.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (infml) a child
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I am taking the kids (= my children) to the zoo this afternoon.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 自始至终，一直
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I am with you all the way.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 街坊;四邻
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She is well-known in the neighborhood for her charitable（慈善的）work.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) a little bit, in some way or degree 有几分,有点儿
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It was kind of odd that he didn't come.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 失去联系
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I am trying to get in touch with my brother; he emigrated to Australia, and I lost touch with him.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 几个;一对，一双
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Across the street there are a couple of police officers standing guard.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 家伙;伙计
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He's quite a nice guy when you get to know him.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (infml) unfortunate; difficult; strong 不幸的;困难的;坚固的;坚强的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The government took tough measures to limit the money supply.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 挂记在心头
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She looks very worried; I wonder what is on her mind.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (与...)保持联系，保持接触
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I haven't really kept in touch with people I knew at school.

NewWords.WordPhrase: happen, occur , esp. unexpectedly (尤指意想不到地)发生，出现
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I'll let you know if anything comes up.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. lift (the shoulders) slightly 耸(肩)
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She just shrugged (her shoulders), saying she didn't know and didn't care.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  try very hard to persuade 力劝，催促
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They urged us to give our support.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. delay 推迟，使延期
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We're postponing our holiday until August.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 提及，谈到;参考，查阅
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Use this dictionary for easy reference.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. completely 完全地,极其   absolute a.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I'm absolutely starving (= very hungry).

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (家人、朋友、同事等久别后的)重聚
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We hold an annual reunion of former students of the college.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (of time) pass (时间)逝去
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Two years went by.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) stay in or near a place, not doing very much 闲荡;徘徊
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They normally hang out in the pub.

NewWords.WordPhrase: sometimes, at times
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I write to him every now and then.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. almost all; generally 几乎全部; 多半，大体
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She uses her car mostly for driving to work.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.(infml) (used to add force) very great; very bad or unpleasant 非常的, 极大的; 可怕的，糟糕的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It was awful to see him in such pain.

NewWords.WordPhrase: become too upset to speak (因激动等)哽得说不出话;堵塞  choke v. (使)窒息;堵塞
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Losing my job left me completely choked up; I was so upset that I didn't know what to say.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 目的地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The parcel was sent to the wrong destination.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. 略过,跳过;跳跃
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The speaker kept skipping from one subject to another.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. showing or causing sadness 伤心的，悲伤的   sorrow n.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We all share your sorrow over this sad loss.

NewWords.WordPhrase: far away
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You can see the ancient ruins in the distance.

NewWords.WordPhrase: at once
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He wants to see you right away.
